thread.title: Vogue accused of photoshopping cover to make plus-sized model look thinner
thread.title_full: Vogue accused of photoshopping cover to make plus-sized model look thinner

author: Adam Boult
title: Vogue accused of photoshopping cover to make plus-sized model look thinner
text:
Vogue accused of photoshopping cover to make plus-sized model look thinner The March 2017 Vogue cover Credit: Conde Nast Adam Boult 9 February 2017 ‚Ä¢ 10:44am 
F ashion bible Vogue has been criticised by eagle-eyed followers on social media over the cover of its latest issue. 
The cover photo features seven top models dressed in black turtlenecks and patterned bikini bottoms. They are, from left to right, Liu Wen, Ashley Graham, Kendall Jenner, Gigi Hadid, Imaan Hammam, Adwoa Aboah, and Vittoria Ceretti. Credit: Cond√© Nast 
G igi Hadid's arm is shown resting on Ashley Graham's waist - and critics claim the arm has been photoshopped to lengthen it, in order to make Ms Graham look smaller. Credit: Cond√© Nast 
T hey also point out that Ms Graham is the only one of the seven models to be posing with her hand on her thigh - prompting speculation that she was instructed to stand like that to make herself look slimmer. Bit of a shame that Ashley Graham was the only model who had to use her arm to cover her thigh ü§î pic.twitter.com/Vw6u9Wb9ej ‚Äî Jessica Barrett (@jess_barrett) February 8, 2017 How LONG is Gigi's arm and hand on the Vogue cover?! üòÇüòÇüôà ‚Äî Chantelle H (@Miss_ChantelleH) February 8, 2017 Anyone else wondering what's happened Gigi's arm/hand? üòÇ #vogue pic.twitter.com/kd5CZYeF3s ‚Äî Imogen Gould (@swimogen) February 8, 2017 
O n Instagram one follower wrote: ‚ÄúShame on you for this, Gigi‚Äôs arm is clearly photoshopped to look longer to cover Ashley‚Äôs belly. Also, having Ashley drop her hand to make her leg look slimmer is shocking.‚Äù 
Another said: ‚ÄúWhat is wrong with Gigi‚Äôs arm and hand? Obviously photoshopped, if not her fingers are damn long and stretched." 
"So hypocritical to put the plus size model on the cover, but then just modify the picture do that she appears 'less' plus size," another wrote. 
However, Graham hit back at the critics, replying on Instagram: ‚ÄúI chose to pose like that. No one told me to do anything." Watch | Bella Hadid and Ashley Graham express love for each other 01:52 
I n 2016 Ashley Graham became the first plus-sized model to cover Sports Illustrated as well as appearing on the cover of Cosmopolitan and Maxim. 
Discussing the 'cult of thinness' in the Vogue cover story , she says: ‚ÄúSixty-seven percent of the women in America wear a size 14 or larger. Sixty-seven percent. 
"Maybe you could ignore those consumers before, but now, thanks to social media, they‚Äôre making their voices heard. Women are demanding that brands give them what they want. And what they want is to be visible.‚Äù
